wikipedia_page.main: John Pickering (ca.1815 – 15 October 1891) was a politician in the early days of the colony of South Australia.

link_mentions.page: Members of the South Australian House of Assembly, 1865–1868
Members of the South Australian House of Assembly, 1868–1870
response: : The seat of West Torrens MHA was declared vacant on 20 January 1870 due to George Bean's non-attendance. John Pickering won the resulting by-election on 10 February.

link_mentions.page: Members of the South Australian House of Assembly, 1871–1875
Members of the South Australian House of Assembly, 1875–1878
List of South Australian House of Assembly by-elections

response: * John Pickering (dramatist), author of the play Horestes first published in 1567
* John Pickering (soldier) (died 1645), colonel of a regiment in the New Model Army
* John Pickering (judge) (1737–1805), American politician and judge
* John Pickering (Massachusetts politician), List of Speakers of the Massachusetts House of Representatives
* John Pickering (Australian politician), South Australian politician
* John Pickering (musician), lead singer with The Picks, US vocal trio of the 1950s
* John Pickering (footballer) (1944–2001), professional footballer, coach and manager
* John Pickering Putnam (1847–1917), architect of numerous buildings in Boston, MA

He was elected, with H. B. T. Strangways, to the Fifth Parliament (1868–1870) for the District of West Torrens of the South Australian House of Assembly, on 21 April 1868, the first SA-colony-born person to achieve this. On 19 November 1869Torrens Trade Protection South Australian Register 18 November 1869 p.2 accessed 2 April 2011 with J. A. BeanShipping Intelligence South Australian Register 19 November 1869 p.2 accessed 2 April 2011 he left for London on business, but his application for leave of absence was refused by Parliament, despite a petition from his constituents.Leave of Absence South Australian Register 9 December 1869 p.2 accessed 3 April 2011Little is known of J.A. Bean fellow member (and Secretary) of the short-lived protectionist Industrial League. He may be Arthur Bean or someone not closely related. His seat was declared vacant on 29 January 1870, due to his "failure to attend". While away he prospected for diamonds in Cape Town,The Late M. George J. Davies South Australian Register 16 December 1872 p.5 accessed 8 April 2011 with some success,Concerning People, (Obituary of G.T. Bean), The Register 8 April 1912 p.4 accessed 18 March 2011 not returning until 1878.The Mail News South Australian Register 10 August 1878 p.5 accessed 6 April 2011 John Pickering won the resulting by-election on 10 February 1870, and the Fifth Parliament was dissolved on 2 March 1870. His brother W. H. Bean successfully stood for West Torrens at the election for the Sixth Parliament.House of Assembly 1868–1870 & 1870–1871 , Statistical Record of the Legislature 1836–2007, Parliament of SA, pp.53, 54, 100 & 114.

response: Hussey was involved in the elections of 1871, when he helped return John Pickering to the seat of West Torrens.
